name: Manjushri
description: Manjushri (Sanskrit: 'Gentle Glory' or 'Sweet Splendor') is the bodhisattva of transcendent wisdom (prajna) in Mahayana and Vajrayana Buddhism, one of the most important and widely venerated bodhisattvas across all Buddhist traditions. He embodies the perfection of wisdom that realizes emptiness (sunyata) and cuts through the fundamental ignorance (avidya) binding beings to the cycle of suffering. Manjushri is typically depicted as a beautiful sixteen-year-old youth, symbolizing the eternal freshness and vitality of wisdom. His right hand wields a flaming sword that severs the bonds of ignorance and wrong views, while his left hand holds the Prajnaparamita Sutra (Perfection of Wisdom scripture) close to his heart, often supported by a blue lotus. He sits on a lion throne, representing the fearless roar of dharma that silences all doubt. Manjushri is invoked by students, scholars, and practitioners seeking clarity of mind, sharp intellect, eloquence, and deep understanding of Buddhist philosophy. In Tibetan Buddhism, great masters like Tsongkhapa and Je Mipham are considered emanations of Manjushri, and he is central to practices aimed at developing prajna-paramita.
title: Bodhisattva of Transcendent Wisdom
attributes: Seated on lion or lion throne
summary: Manjushri is the great bodhisattva of wisdom in Buddhism, wielding the sword that cuts through ignorance and embodying the perfection of transcendent insight into the nature of reality.

relationships.triad: Forms trinity with Avalokiteshvara (compassion) and Vajrapani (power)

originsAndHistory.title: Origins & History
originsAndHistory.content: Manjushri emerged as a major bodhisattva figure in early Mahayana Buddhism (1st-2nd century CE), appearing prominently in sutras like the Vimalakirti and Lotus Sutra. His cult developed particularly in India, Nepal, and later flourished in Tibet, China (as Wenshu), and Japan (as Monju). Mount Wutai in China became his sacred mountain, attracting pilgrims for over a millennium. In Tibet, Manjushri assumed special importance, with great scholar-saints like Tsongkhapa (founder of the Gelug school) and Mipham Rinpoche considered his emanations. The Manjushri-namasamgiti became one of the most recited texts in Vajrayana Buddhism.

attributesAndCharacteristics.title: Attributes & Characteristics
attributesAndCharacteristics.content: Manjushri's iconography is rich with meaning. His eternally youthful appearance (usually depicted as sixteen years old) symbolizes the ever-fresh, vibrant nature of wisdom that never ages or decays. The flaming sword represents discriminating wisdom (prajna) that cuts through the darkness of ignorance with surgical precision, severing attachment to wrong views. The Prajnaparamita text represents the scriptural transmission of wisdom teachings. The blue lotus indicates that wisdom, like the lotus, grows from the mud of samsara but remains unstained. The lion beneath his throne roars the dharma fearlessly, overwhelming all opposition with truth.

mythologicalSignificance.title: Mythological Significance
mythologicalSignificance.content: In Buddhist cosmology, Manjushri represents the wisdom aspect of enlightenment itself - the prajna that penetrates the ultimate nature of reality (sunyata/emptiness). He is sometimes called the 'mother of all Buddhas' because prajna-paramita (perfection of wisdom) is the quality that gives birth to enlightenment. The Vimalakirti Sutra presents him as the only bodhisattva capable of dialoguing with the enlightened layman Vimalakirti about profound emptiness teachings. In tantric Buddhism, Manjushri appears in multiple forms - peaceful, wrathful (as Yamantaka/Vajrabhairava), and various colored manifestations for different practices.

culturalImpact.title: Cultural Impact
culturalImpact.content: Manjushri has profoundly influenced Buddhist intellectual culture. In East Asia, he is patron of scholars, students, and artists. Mount Wutai in China, his sacred abode, has been a major pilgrimage destination for centuries, visited by emperors and commoners alike. In Tibet, invoking Manjushri before study and debate is standard practice in monastic education. His mantra 'Om Ah Ra Pa Tsa Na Dhih' is recited to enhance intelligence, memory, and understanding. In Japan, Monju is one of the most beloved bodhisattvas, patron of the Tendai school's scholarly tradition. His image appears in countless temples, thangkas, and statues across Asia.
